A Bill to amend the Increase of Rent and Mortgage Interest (Restrictions) Act, 1920.Be it enacted, etc.1. Where a landlord has served notice on a tenant of his intention to Increase the rent and that notice would have been a valid notice under the Increase of Rent and Mortgage Interest (RestrJrctiona) Act, 1909, (hereinafter referred to as the "principal Act") if it had been accompanied by a notice determining the tenancy, the notice of Intention to increase the rent shall be deemed to be and always to have been valid: Provided that -(1) Nothing In this Act shall enable a landlord to recover from a tenant (a) any increase of rent accrued before the first day of December, 1922, which but for this Act would be irrecoverable, or (b) any sum recovered by a tenant from a landlord before that date (whether by deduction from rent or otherwise) and(2) Any sum recoverable from a tenant by virtue of this Act in respect of the period between the first day of December, 1922, and the date of the introduction (? passing) of this Act shall be payable by instalments, en instalment not exceeding one-tenth of the standard rent being payable with each payment of rent.2. This Act may be cited as the Rent Restriction (Amendment) Act, 1923, and shall be construed as one with the principal Act,
